PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name: George Herbert Brigham
2. Your address: Box 127, Keewatin, Sask.
3. Date: June 1st, 1965
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and county): Borthwell—Kenora County—Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Wallace Andrew Brigham
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? May 5th, 1906

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible:
   - Kenora, Ontario
   - Keewatin, Saskatchewan
   - Keewatin, Saskatchewan

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under ten or you may use "I was a small child.") I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To find work and make a better life for my family.

10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad advertisements? Word of mouth through friends?

   I came to Saskatchewan in October 1905 and was quickly taken with the community and came to love it. I decided to stay there and raise three families out on the farming land.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our only travelling the first 2 years was to Saskatoon for mail and supplies and to pick up the odd tile to turn a few dollars. And a couple of trips to townelling to be able to go back to build with and teach to roof and build up about 75 miles by O.P. Train. In the fall of 1908 we were able to get back and supply from Sask. 45 miles then in the fall of 1909 we were able to get some supplies from Kindersley about 25 miles and by the fall of 1910 the town of Kindersley had got electric and only about 9 miles almost like living in town.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our only travelling the first 3 years was to Saskatoon for mail and supplies and to pick up the odd tile to make a few dollars. And a couple of trips to surrounding townships for supplies. We had no cars and buildings about 75 miles by Oxt Tramway. In the fall of 1908 we were able to get Beal and Ida's farm built 45 miles from us. In the fall of 1909 we were able to get some supplies from Fairholme about 35 miles and by the fall of 1910 the town of Strathbrot had been built only about 9 miles almost like living in town.

The first school in the town Beaulieu Hill district was named Ramly. The first baby born in the district was a twin girl. They called her Ethel and named the P.O. Ethelburg. Believe the name was Gunnison (or)

The school was named after Duncan McMillan. The Eaton Point

(School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3). 

The school named after Dunstan MacMillan. The Elkhorn Point school was named after Elkhorn Point. They called her Elkhorn Point.
An elderly Blankenese man said his son came from Germany back by the name of Blankenese, and a fine old man and he and the son became quite important in the district but none called him Blankenese if ever always the Old Genius and so the year was by the railroad came in a store was built also school and the Post Office was moved to the place and the village named Beaufield.

The Town of Keruland was named after Sir Robert Kerr, one of the three important officials. His name first spelled Kerr, Robert, later changed to Keruland, started in the summer of 1910.
Later an elderly Beaubien man and his son came from Easternzy back by the name of Jelivick, and a fine old man and he and the son became quite important in the district; but none called him Mr. Jelivick it was always the Old Beau, and as the years went by the railroad came in a store was built also a school and the Post Office was moved to the store and the village named Beanfield.

The Town of Ferrobert was named after Sir Robert Ferro, one of the three important C.P.R. officials. It was first spelled Terra Robert but later changed to Ferrobert. It was started in the summer of 1910.
